content.description: Start on a excellent left facing side pull then throw for a sloping hold above lip, or use intermediate holds to gain lip.  Work your feet up and use another sloper to top out.
content.location: To the right of the clean arete on the Arete Boulder

content.description: A boulder problem characterized by one of the best underclings that I have ever utilized.  Bump the right hand up from a sloping edge to intermediate holds, then match on a small jug and pull up for the topout.   Sit start.
content.location: Looking uphill, with the smowmobile trail and Rt 27 behind you, it is about 75 feet to the right of the arete.  Its the next boulder over from Moosehead on tap.

content.description: Sit start on two great but painful finger pockets.  Getting your weight above your feet is the crux.  Top out on a cool triangular hold and small flake/side pull.  An excellent problem for warmup laps.
content.location: Looking uphill, right (north) of the Arete boulder.

content.description: About 20 ft to the left of the arete boulder is a boulder which has a clean triangular shaped slightly overhainging face.  Sitstart the bottom right side of the face, and use the featured lip of the face to gain the top of the boulder.
content.protection: Pad, spotter.  The landing isn't perfect, but a pad and spotter will make it a safe problem.
content.location: 20 ft to the left of the arete boulder, looking up hill with the snowmobile trail behind you.

content.description: Nice clean moderate arete with a technical crux at the beginning.  Start down to the right on the arete feature, and work up and left until good smears can be had on the arete itself.  Try not to fall on the topout.
content.protection: pad and spotter may be helpful.
content.location: 50 ft uphill from the snowmobile trail.

content.description:
Secluded boulders hidden in the woods.  The climbing consists mostly of vertical face climbing, using numerous rails, flakes, assorted face holds on solid rock.  The largest boulder is a House sized boulder which has a some of the earliest established climbs on it. 

  There is lots of potential for new problems if you're willing to put in some time cleaning the rock.
